problems.title: Two Sum
problems.statement: Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return the indices of the two numbers that add up to target. You may assume each input has exactly one solution, and you cannot use the same element twice.
problems.example:
Input: nums = [2,7,11,15], target = 9
Output: [0,1]
Explanation: nums[0] + nums[1] = 2 + 7 = 9

problems.title: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock
problems.statement: You are given an array prices where prices[i] is the price of a given stock on the ith day. Find the maximum profit you can achieve by buying and selling the stock once. If no profit can be made, return 0.
problems.example:
Input: prices = [7,1,5,3,6,4]
Output: 5
Explanation: Buy on day 2 (price = 1) and sell on day 5 (price = 6), profit = 6-1 = 5

problems.title: Move Zeroes
problems.statement: Given an integer array nums, move all 0's to the end while maintaining the relative order of non-zero elements. Do this in-place without making a copy of the array.
problems.example:
Input: nums = [0,1,0,3,12]
Output: [1,3,12,0,0]
Explanation: All zeros are moved to the end while maintaining the order of non-zero elements

problems.title: Maximum Subarray (Kadane)
problems.statement: Given an integer array nums, find the contiguous subarray (containing at least one number) which has the largest sum and return its sum. Use Kadane's algorithm to solve optimally.
problems.example:
Input: nums = [-2,1,-3,4,-1,2,1,-5,4]
Output: 6
Explanation: The subarray [4,-1,2,1] has the largest sum = 6

problems.title: Container With Most Water
problems.statement: You are given an integer array height of length n. There are n vertical lines drawn such that the two endpoints of the ith line are (i, 0) and (i, height[i]). Find two lines that together with the x-axis form a container, such that the container contains the most water.
problems.example:
Input: height = [1,8,6,2,5,4,8,3,7]
Output: 49
Explanation: The vertical lines at index 1 and 8 form a container with area = 7 * 7 = 49

problems.title: Valid Anagram
problems.statement: Given two strings s and t, return true if t is an anagram of s, and false otherwise. An anagram is a word formed by rearranging the letters of another word using all original letters exactly once.
problems.example:
Input: s = "anagram", t = "nagaram"
Output: true
Explanation: Both strings contain the same characters with the same frequencies

problems.title: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
problems.statement: Given a string s, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.
problems.example:
Input: s = "abcabcbb"
Output: 3
Explanation: The answer is "abc", with the length of 3

problems.title: Group Anagrams
problems.statement: Given an array of strings strs, group the anagrams together. You can return the answer in any order.
problems.example:
Input: strs = ["eat","tea","tan","ate","nat","bat"]
Output: [["bat"],["nat","tan"],["ate","eat","tea"]]
Explanation: Strings with same character frequencies are grouped together

problems.title: Longest Palindromic Substring
problems.statement: Given a string s, return the longest palindromic substring in s. A palindrome is a string that reads the same forwards and backwards.
problems.example:
Input: s = "babad"
Output: "bab"
Explanation: "aba" is also a valid answer

problems.title: Valid Parentheses
problems.statement: Given a string s containing just the characters '(', ')', '{', '}', '[' and ']', determine if the input string is valid. An input string is valid if: open brackets must be closed by the same type of brackets, and open brackets must be closed in the correct order.
problems.example:
Input: s = "()[]{}"
Output: true
Explanation: All brackets are properly matched and closed in correct order

problems.title: Reverse Linked List
problems.statement: Given the head of a singly linked list, reverse the list and return the reversed list. You must do this in-place.
problems.example:
Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5]
Output: [5,4,3,2,1]
Explanation: The linked list is reversed in-place

problems.title: Detect Cycle in Linked List
problems.statement: Given head, the head of a linked list, determine if the linked list has a cycle in it. Return true if there is a cycle in the linked list. Otherwise, return false.
problems.example:
Input: head = [3,2,0,-4], pos = 1
Output: true
Explanation: There is a cycle where the tail connects to the 1st node (0-indexed)

problems.title: Merge Two Sorted Lists
problems.statement: You are given the heads of two sorted linked lists list1 and list2. Merge the two lists into one sorted list and return the head of the merged linked list.
problems.example:
Input: list1 = [1,2,4], list2 = [1,3,4]
Output: [1,1,2,3,4,4]
Explanation: The merged list is sorted

problems.title: Remove Nth Node From End
problems.statement: Given the head of a linked list, remove the nth node from the end of the list and return the head of the list.
problems.example:
Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5], n = 2
Output: [1,2,3,5]
Explanation: The 2nd node from the end (4) is removed

problems.title: Intersection of Two Linked Lists
problems.statement: Given the heads of two singly linked-lists headA and headB, return the node at which the two lists intersect. If the two linked lists have no intersection at all, return null.
problems.example:
Input: intersectVal = 8, listA = [4,1,8,4,5], listB = [5,6,1,8,4,5], skipA = 2, skipB = 3
Output: 8
Explanation: The lists intersect at node with value 8

problems.title: Min Stack
problems.statement: Design a stack that supports push, pop, top, and retrieving the minimum element in constant time. Implement the MinStack class with all required methods.
problems.example:
Input: ["MinStack","push","push","push","getMin","pop","top","getMin"]
[[],[-2],[0],[-3],[],[],[],[]]
Output: [null,null,null,null,-3,null,0,-2]
Explanation: MinStack maintains minimum element at each state

problems.title: Next Greater Element
problems.statement: Given a circular integer array nums (meaning the last element's next element is the first element), return an array ans of the same length where ans[i] is the next greater element to nums[i]. If there is no greater element, output -1.
problems.example:
Input: nums = [1,2,1]
Output: [2,-1,2]
Explanation: For 1st element, next greater is 2. For 2nd element, no greater exists. For 3rd element, next greater is 2 (circular)

problems.title: Evaluate Reverse Polish Notation
problems.statement: Evaluate the value of an arithmetic expression in Reverse Polish Notation. Valid operators are +, -, *, and /. Each operand may be an integer or another expression.
problems.example:
Input: tokens = ["2","1","+","3","*"]
Output: 9
Explanation: ((2 + 1) * 3) = 9

problems.title: Daily Temperatures
problems.statement: Given an array of integers temperatures representing the daily temperatures, return an array answer such that answer[i] is the number of days you have to wait after the ith day to get a warmer temperature.
problems.example:
Input: temperatures = [73,74,75,71,69,72,76,73]
Output: [1,1,4,2,1,1,0,0]
Explanation: For day 0, next warmer day is day 1 (1 day wait)

problems.title: Implement Queue Using Stacks
problems.statement: Implement a first in first out (FIFO) queue using only two stacks. The implemented queue should support all functions of a normal queue (push, peek, pop, and empty).
problems.example:
Input: ["MyQueue","push","push","peek","pop","empty"]
[[],[1],[2],[],[],[]]
Output: [null,null,null,1,1,false]
Explanation: Queue operates with FIFO order using two stacks

problems.title: Climbing Stairs
problems.statement: You are climbing a staircase. It takes n steps to reach the top. Each time you can climb 1 or 2 steps. In how many distinct ways can you climb to the top?
problems.example:
Input: n = 3
Output: 3
Explanation: There are three ways: 1+1+1, 1+2, 2+1

problems.title: House Robber
problems.statement: You are a professional robber planning to rob houses along a street. You cannot rob two adjacent houses. Given an integer array nums representing the amount of money in each house, return the maximum amount of money you can rob without alerting the police.
problems.example:
Input: nums = [2,7,9,3,1]
Output: 12
Explanation: Rob house 1 (2), house 3 (9) and house 5 (1) for a total of 12

problems.title: Longest Increasing Subsequence
problems.statement: Given an integer array nums, return the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence.
problems.example:
Input: nums = [10,9,2,5,3,7,101,18]
Output: 4
Explanation: The longest increasing subsequence is [2,3,7,101], length = 4

problems.title: Coin Change
problems.statement: You are given an integer array coins representing coins of different denominations and an integer amount representing a total amount of money. Return the fewest number of coins that you need to make up that amount.
problems.example:
Input: coins = [1,2,5], amount = 11
Output: 3
Explanation: 11 = 5 + 5 + 1 (3 coins)

problems.title: Longest Common Subsequence
problems.statement: Given two strings text1 and text2, return the length of their longest common subsequence. A subsequence of a string is a new string generated from the original string with some characters (can be none) deleted without changing the relative order of the remaining characters.
problems.example:
Input: text1 = "abcde", text2 = "ace"
Output: 3
Explanation: The longest common subsequence is "ace" with length 3
